{{Unnamed}} "'''Ere iron was found or tree was hewn'''" is the first line of a short poem recited by [[Gandalf]] to [[Théoden|King Théoden]], when asked about what caused the summoning of the [[Huorns]] during the [[Battle of the Hornburg]]. Could it have been an act of "[[Magic|wizardry]]?", asked Théoden. Gandalf said that it was "a power far older", and went on to recite the poem. Théoden identified Gandalf's lines of verse as a [[Riddle-game|riddle]].{{TT|III8}} ==The poem== ''Ere iron was found or tree was hewn,
When young was mountain under moon;
Ere ring was made, or wrought was woe,
It walked the forests long ago.'' ==Composition== The poem contains [[Wikipedia:Iamb (poetry)|four iambs in each line]], and the lines [[Wikipedia:Couplet|rhyme in pairs]].{{webcite|author='Kamelen' (alias)|articleurl=http://tolkien.mbor.se/ohlmarxisten/visadikt.php?dikt=Gandalf%27s+Riddle+of+the+Ents|articlename=Gandalf's Riddle of the Ents/Gandalfs gåta om enterna [Swedish-language]|dated=17 October 2016|website=[http://tolkien.mbor.se/ tolkien.mbor.se]|accessed=5 December 2016}} [[Verlyn Flieger]] has described the poem as a piece of "folk verse".[[Verlyn Flieger]], "[http://books.google.com/books?id=B0loOBA3ejIC&pg=PA527&lpg=PA527&dq=Ere+iron+was+found+or+tree+was+hewn&source=bl&ots=hiJzeIbaXi&sig=g0Et2UDoSyXUNrSHIMVyaIPQCfA&hl=sv&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjsqK_f5N3QAhXCDCwKHa-TBowQ6AEIRzAG#v=onepage&q=Ere%20iron%20was%20found%20or%20tree%20was%20hewn&f=false Poems by Tolkien: ''The Lord of the Rings'']", in [[Michael D.C. Drout]] (ed), ''[[J.R.R. Tolkien Encyclopedia: Scholarship and Critical Assessment]]'' ==Name== Among [[Tolkien fandom|fans]], the poem is commonly called '''Gandalf's Riddle of the Ents'''.{{webcite|author='NenyaGold' (alias)|articleurl=http://www.councilofelrond.com/poem/gandalfs-riddle-of-the-ents/|articlename=Gandalf's Riddle of the Ents|dated=|website=[http://www.councilofelrond.com www.councilofelrond.com]|accessed=5 December 2016}}{{webcite|author=|articleurl=http://www.henneth-annun.net/things_view.cfm?thid=117|articlename=Gandalf's Riddle of the Ents|dated=29 September 2003|website=[http://www.henneth-annun.net/ www.henneth-annun.net]|accessed=5 December 2016}}{{webcite|author=|articleurl=http://lotr.wikia.com/wiki/Gandalf's_Riddle_to_the_Ents|articlename=Gandalf's Riddle to the Ents|dated=9 August 2016|website=[http://lotr.wikia.com/ lotr.wikia.com]|accessed=5 December 2016}} ==Inspiration== It has been noted that Tolkien re-used a phrase from ''[[The Lay of Aotrou and Itroun]]'':{{webcite|author=Alan Reynolds|articleurl=http://www.facebook.com/groups/TheTolkienSociety.EducationalCharity/permalink/10154585138321068/|articlename=Tolkien Society Facebook group post|dated=5 December 2016|website=FB|accessed=5 December 2016}} {{blockquote|ere fire was found or iron hewn,
when young was mountain under moon.|vv. 299-300{{Corrigan|Lay}}, p. 14}} ==See also== *''[[Rhymes of Lore]]'' *[[Poems in The Lord of the Rings|Poems in ''The Lord of the Rings'']] {{title|italics}} {{references}} [[Category:Poems in The Two Towers]]
